lg.l: A summer long the sun and thou Thou. The tauhou/silvereye is a small songbird, distinguished by a white ring around its eye, that was introduced from Australia in the 1850s (“tauhou” translates as “stranger”).
In flowering bush have lingered merry,
Ye both have left the bushlands now,
Where neither flower there is, nor berry,
And insects, as the days turn cold,
Hide deep in bark, and leaf, and mould.
The keen winds and thy plaintive cry
Have come together down the glen;
Thou comest to the haunts of men. Haunts of men. The tauhou/silvereye is found in suburban environments and farmland, as well as forests.
Ah; we desert our gay haunts thus
When life grows cold, unkind to us.
